b"b' Module dependency checking & self '"

b'b\' Have updated modules component to enable more fully formed module dependancies and provisions. Have re-factored code to improve some performance and offer more complete evaluation of required dependencies. This also includes a requirement for a module to have a version number two key methods and one property are now required.. Suspect these will need moving to an  EDIT:Pull request now includes "Installable" interface. This allows for modules to be defined as installable and generate a installation manifest. This does not handle what or how anything is installed just that it is installable and needs running.  The actual  needs to be handled inside the Module itself. This should allow us to be able to allow modules to self update any assets in public or db schema details etc... See Sample module code below class Module implements Installable{  /**   \\\\* define the current module version   \\\\*  \\\\* @var float   */  const VERSION = 0.2; } \''

b"b' I figured the dispatch() method was kinda too long (over 80 lines) to easily extend and override specific behaviors. Therefore I broke it up in smaller parts. All Zend\\\\Mvc\\\\App unittests pass
column11: before as well as after. Some windows line endings were killed in the process.'"

column10: b'b" Looking through this
column11: I\'m thinking we should actually do this a little differently: move the dispatch-specific logic into a listener
column12: as well as the route-specific logic. These listeners should receive the application\'s event manager instance. Then
column13: the Application instance would register these listeners by default
column14: and have a flag for  that registration. This would be a better separation of concerns in many ways
column15: and make the Application class leaner. Thoughts?"'

column10: b'b" I\'m always in favor of separating concerns. I\'m however not enough into the code yet to give a well funded answer to your suggestion
column11: nor am I at this point able to realize it. However
column12: by all means
column13: be my guest ;) ="'

column11: I\'m totaly for that. This would allow us to optimize resources consumption in efficiency-critical applications."'

b'b" [Mail] Refactor headersUse more HeadersInterface instances in Headers implementation rather than manipulate stringsCentralize the render of headers newlines (CRLF) in Headers implementation rather than each HeaderInterface::toString()Delegate headers rendering to the specific header class (toString) [Mail] Changes in Generic headers and HeaderMultiInterfaceGenericMultiHeader now inherits from GenericHeaderHeaderMultiInterface now is independent from HeaderInterface [Mail] Avoid render To: and Cc: headers if doesn\'t have addresses [Mail] Replace line endings for fields (\\\\r\\\\n) with a constant [Mail] Various improvements.Fix a issue with headers being rendered as CRCRLF with SMTP Protocol (ZF2-185)Add test case to detect the above issue and trace the full command sended.Add check in SMTP Transport for require at least one recipient if at least one DATA (header or body) will send per RFC-2821 [![Build Status]url "'

column16: since it doesn\\\'t solve that problem.While it is true that we can know where scalars come from (by tracing what is retrieved from the  )
column17: we cannot really run around the current introduction.This is because is currently a composition of some introspection (  basically is some  -alike functionality) and some actual injection logic.Re-working at this point is surely:1.  something I don\\\'t think I\\\'m able to do
column18: both because I\\\'m not really qualified to handle it and because I never get to do some decent githubbing.2.  a major refactoring of the component So since is currently a mix of reflection logic and injection logic
column19: I\\\'d like to see this PR merged even with the new method :) Also
column20: a refactoring with the idea of "tracing" everything would make much much slower (since we most probably need to separate logic into different classes)
column21: which makes compiling Di almost a requirement for it to be usable
column22: and that is quite a change in its functionality... Please let me know what exactly can be handled within this PR without approaching a  of the class.\''

b"b' Add form row view helper'"
b'b\' This is a utility form view helper that renders a very common use case : label (if specified)
column11: element and element errors. This is more flexible than a magic view helper that would render the all form
column12: as it allows to add specific markup around every elements. Basically
column13: it allows to replace this : <?php  $email = $form->get(\\\'email\\\');  echo $formLabel->openTag() . $email->getAttribute(\\\'label\\\');  echo $this->formInput($email);  echo $this->formElementErrors($email);  echo $formLabel->closeTag();?By this shorter one
column14: making views much more easier to read : formRow($form->get(\\\'email\\\')); ?EDIT : here are some more notes about this PR : if no label is set for a specific element
column15: only the input will be drawn
column16: so you don\\\'t "absolutely" need to set one for every elements to use this helper. For multicheckboxes and radio
column17: I prefered to group them inside field sets (which appears to be the more semantic way to do it) instead of generating "id" for elements to allow nested labels (which is prohibited by HTML
column18: anyway).\''

column10: b'b" I\'m in favor of this being a good next step to rendering a Form in one fell swoop. :)  The forms I\'m typically working on are very custom
column11: and it would be cool to mix and match between a FormRow and custom markup."'

column10: b'b" Thanks for the feedback. I\'ll update this one tomorrow :)."'
b'b\' Oh
column11: which also brings up a situation where a label might wrap other labels for MultiCheckbox or Radio element types: A nested label inside a label is invalid markup I think. Would we want to close the label before the element and rely on the "for" attribute?\''

column10: b'b" Good catch ! I don\'t really know if this is invalid markup
column11: I will check tomorrow. The problem with the for is that we need an id
column12: and we can\'t assume that an id"'

column10: b'b" And we can\'t assume that an id is defined when using this helper."'

b'b\' Dang: url "The label element must not contain any nested label elements." It could be as simple as requiring an "id" attribute be set on the element for the "for" attribute If it isn\\\'t defined
column11: you lose the ability to click on the label to get to the element.\''

column10: b'b" I have added the rowLabelAttributes and the tests for it (as well as the test for element errors). I\'m still not a big fan of the id idea as I already had id clashes cases from the old ZF 1 form... I\'m going to think a little more if we can find another solution. Others
column11: any ideas ? EDIT : one question about coding style : config parameters should be dash_separated ? row_label_attributes instead of rowLabelAttributes ?"'

column10: b'b" Form row now takes into account multicheckboxes and radio buttons
column11: by wrapping them inside a fieldset (therefore
column12: we don\'t need to generate ids). This appears to be the most semantic way to wrapping them if a label is set."'

column10: b'b" @bakura10 There is not explicit rule about the config keys format
column11: but the de facto standard is and I\'m think that is good that format and avoid confussions with the PHP  vars that usually has the same name (in camelCaps) as the option but with the value normalized (casting
column12: etc)"'

column10: b"b' I like this format too
column11: but there should be a strict rule for that... Currently many form view helpers use camelCase.'"

column10: b"b' Made the messages in Zend\\\\Validator more discreet.'"

b'b" The Zend\\\\Validator messages often put the inputted value in the messages. I don\'t think that that is necessary in most cases and often it actually stands of the way of some things. For example
column11: if you have a password field
column12: you don\'t want your password to be exposed to anyone standing behind you if your password doesn\'t conform to the StringLenght validator. In most use cases
column13: the value in the message doesn\'t add much value either
column14: because it usually will be displayed next to the given value. Of course
column15: the \'%value%\' replacement will still be done if anyone does actually wants this in the message. Also
column16: I have left it in the File validators
column17: because in there it means the File name
column18: which actually is usefull in most cases."'

column10: b"b' This pull request [fails]url  (merged c3b46dc4 into 7e444f8e).'"
b"b' @bjyoungblood actually
column11: why are you using too? Personally I see the flash messages as user targeted messages to display short messages in notification style (whether something succeed
column12: failed or whatsoever). As far as I know
column13: the current ZfcUser PRG data is stored inside the flash messenger because of some bugs in Zend\\\\Session (but that was around beta2 iirc). I PRed to get it to Zend\\\\Session
column14: but because of those bugs (back then) it never got merged). There is no need to pull the plugin from the manager then. Just instantiate a and set the expiration hops to 1.  '"

column10: b'b" I tried refactoring ZfcUser to use this quite some time ago and was never able to get setMaxExpirationHops(1) to work properly. I remember i tracked down the problem (but never got it fixed)
column11: but I can\'t remember exactly what it was. I _thought_ it had something to do with me setting up the container via DI
column12: thus it would set the max hops every time the container was pulled for every request
column13: thus constantly resetting the hop count so it was always 0 and never incremented to 1. However
column14: it might actually be a more fundamental bug with the Container and how it counts the hops
column15: I don\'t remember. I ended up using FlashMessenger
column16: because instead of using max hops
column17: it simply unsets messages as they are pulled from the container (we could just duplicate this logic in the PRG plugin as a work-around
column18: but why bother if that\'s pretty much exactly what FlashMessenger does?). Regardless
column19: @bjyoungblood is looking into it now."'

column12: but you might want to set properties to the form after you check the PRG return value.  "'

column10: b'b" @EvanDotPro the point is rather: what if you want to add more variables to your return? I am not talking about the return of the response
column11: but the return of the form instance. In 99% of my form usage cases
column12: I also return other variables. So something like this Can be much more DRY implemented by this: Same holds if you want to change form options (must be done twice) or other calls if you want to call those when you\'re sure you do not have a Response returned (eg your calls are expensive and not done in the R phase of PRG). But anyways
column13: we\'re all smart enough to see you should refactor it when your controller gets this far ;)"'

column11: console-based MVC applications. ## Theory of operationAll console related components are grouped in the namespace.and have been enhanced to support console requests.When is run from a console environment (i.e. in a shell or command prompt window) it will  switch from http logic to console logic.In this environment
column12: the equivalent of a _Http request_ ( etc.) is a _Console request_ (containing script name
column13: command-line parameters and environment information).The request is passed to a console-aware _Router_._Console Router_ operates and analyzes command-line parameters
column14: parsing them and matching against a _console route definition__Console Router_ config is loaded from  .Routes should be defined in  .An example of a console route could be:  This route expects 2 constant arguments  .  After that
column15: a single variable argument  .  An optional argument (or its shorthand  )  An optional argument.  An optional argumentWhen a console route matches it will behave analogical to an http route trying to dispatch the request with an action controller
column16: obtained from _Service Manager_.Action controller can handle a request in several ways:  1. It can directly retrieve a from Service Manager it allows reading from and writing to console window
column17: bypassing the MVC layer and enabling interactivity with the user. 2. It can return a instance that will be shown in console window  3. It can return a that will be show in console window.## Standard console request flow1. We are assuming zf2 application is run in a console window.2. The entry point could be any php script. A standard []url  will work just fine.3. **Zend\\\\Application::init()** **Zend\\\\Application::boostrap()** 1. creates and returns   2. creates and returns   3. by default loads parameters from and environment information from  . 4. creates and returns with configuration loaded from   5. creates and returns  4.  **Zend\\\\Application::run()** 1. **$events->trigger(MvcEvent::EVENT_ROUTE ... ) routing phase**  1. is routed  2. User-supplied command-line arguments are matched against defined routes.   3. The first route that matches
column18: wins.  4. Matching parameters are stored in objects. 2. **$events->trigger(MvcEvent::EVENT_DISPATCH ... ) dispatching phase**  1. In case any route matches
column19: an action controller is loaded and invoked.  2. If the action returns a  : will transform the string into a object.  3. If the action returns the response will immediately be shown in console window.  4. If the action returns it will not be transformed. 3. **$events->trigger(MvcEvent::EVENT_RENDER
column20: $event) rendering phase**  1. NOTE: Current version does not perform any form of  on the result coming from action controller. There is no support for templating or markup. This is planned and will be discussed soon.  2. If the resulting contains children (i.e. several actions provided some text)
column21: results will be concatenated.  3. transforms into  . 4. **$events->trigger(MvcEvent::EVENT_FINISH
column22: $event); output phase**  1. invokes   2. Result is echoed to console window  3.  .## Route not found flow In case no arguments have been provided  no console route matched user-provided arguments

User-supplied command-line arguments are matched against defined routes.   3. **No route can be matched** 2. **$events->trigger(MvcEvent::EVENT_ROUTE ... ) dispatch error occured**  1.    2. is created with (which on most OS means application error)  3. Create a _console banner_:   1. Go through all     2. For all modules that implement call method that is expected to return a string.   3. All banners are joined together with a newline  .   4. In case there are no banners    4. Create _console usage information_:   1. Go through all     2. For all modules that implement call method that is expected to return a string or array   3. If an array is returned

b'b" ### WARNING!!! When opening FILES CHANGED tab on GitHub it takes a longer while to display an can hang your browser**### Rationale This PR adds to zf2. It is independent
column11: has no requirements and is an utility class. **UniDecoder** is used to convert utf-8 strings into plain-ASCII equivalents
column12: transliterating accents and special characters into their ASCII equivalents. The component is loosely-based on [Python Unidecoder]url  and the transliteration is based on a database in form of conversion tables. I want UniDecoder to find it\'s way into ZF 2.0.0 because I need it for Console transliteration in case the console is non-utf8 compatible and the Application tries to output multibyte strings. Without transliteration
column13: the whole output will become unreadable and certain special characters can modify remote session settings
column14: clear the screen or throw cursor around the screen. ### Basic usage The class is a static class
column15: similar to and offers a single method. Below is an example usage:  "'

column10: b'b" @marc-mabe 1. does not do what this component does.2. is the best place

I know and I\'m against moving that into Stdlib. _Especially_ if it was to merged with UniDecoder and possibly slugifier (if we ported that too from @DASPRiD)4. and work on arrays and strings. Notice that these are built-in datatypes in PHP. Multibyte strings are an external standard. Because PHP uses for byte data
column13: that\'s why multibyte strings in PHP are held in but similarities end here. There are multiple standards for multibyte strings
column14: tens of rules and thousands of characters across different tables. PHP 6 was rumored to introduce built-in
column15: native multibyte string support
column16: but until that time
column17: it\'s still an external
column18: complex and expensive standard. It must not be squeezed in just because there **might** be many components using it.5. consists of 190 new files. That\'s the main reason it lives inside it\'s NS under  . This allows for easily excluding it
column19: or including on-demand by people."'

column10: b'b\' The commit was born out of following problem: Object A is a Doctrine entity with a 1:1 relation to object B. An instance of A is stored in the database
column11: but has no related instance of B yet.We generated a form for this with a Form for A and a Fieldset for B.Since it is necessary to provide an object for the form as well as for the fieldset
column12: we initially provided new instances for A and B during the form generation process. After querying the database for an instance of A Form::bind() is used to bind the instance of A to the form and overwrites the initially set A in the from. This works quite well
column13: until you want to store them
column14: because B was never added to Doctrines Unit of Work which is needed to persist it. (Result: B was never stored)  So we tried to add B to the Unit of Work during the generation process. This is working for the initially described use case when an instance of A is provided but the related B instance is not existing yet. If A has a related B instance
column15: we get this instance already managed by the Unit of Work. (Result: B is stored twice) So we need to remove the initially added B instance from the Unit of Work if a new object is set in the Fieldset. (btw: This gets even more complex if you want to use inherited objects) We\\\'re finally came up with a better solution (overwriting Form::bindValues()) but this was an use case in which setObject() was needed. But I like to share my experiences during the work on this and provide some proposals for better extensibility:1. The FieldsetInterface describes a form representation of one entity while the Collection is used for multiple entities. But since there is no CollectionInterface
column16: you have to rely on the Collection class (including the functionality) if you want to implement a form element which is used for more than one object. 2. The Fieldset provides a setter for the object
column17: which cannot be used with the Collection class because the function is (implicit) typed to object and you can\\\'t pass an array as parameter. It seems that this has lead to the "hack" implementation in Fieldset (Line 576 583) where the setter is explicitely not used. Instead Collection should override the setObject() method and accept arrays. (This commit does not include this)3. According to 2. the setter should always be used to set the object to allow custom logic at this point. It\\\'s hard to describe a common use case for this
column18: but it should be generally possible (see our initial problem above)4. The check if an object can be set in a fieldset ($fieldset->object && $object instanceof $fieldset->object) should be handled by the fieldset itself. Like $fieldset->acceptObject($object). So the Fieldset class does not have to know the implementation details of the concrete fieldset. Currently we need to know that Collection behaves different than the Fieldset and an additional OR is needed to check if the $object is valid.  \''

b"b' We have **[filter classes]url  in ZF2 to determine if the event should be handle by a writer. And
column11: the error level strategy is the same functionality as the [PriorityFilter]url  I ask myself if we should throw an exception when we set the formatter...'"

column10: b'b" @stefankleff Can you write up:Usage -give some examples and use casesHow this differs from the filter system already present in Zend\\\\Log From what I can see
column11: our log filters may already do what you\'re trying to accomplish here
column12: but it\'s hard to tell
column13: because I\'m not 100% clear from the patch how you intend it to be used."'

column10: b'b" The FingersCrossedWriter is based on a simple assumption:If I log something with a level which is critical
column11: I want to know why this happened.Usually you log everything with a priority higher than the  priority the priority filter allows. This could mess up your logfile or your debug output.This writer does not write anything until a certain priority is exceeded But then every logged message is shown
column12: even with a lower priority. This could help to analyse why the critical message was logged without messing up the log output in cases where no critical message was logged. It\'s probably better explained at url  . This is where monolog (which is basically the default symfony logger) has the idea from."'

column10: b"b' Thank you for your changes!'"
b"b' Fix for ZF2-512'"
b"b' The fix is dead simple: prepare objects for serialization using magic __sleep. Only downside to this fix is that it actually loses information
column11: as the references to plugins are lost. I think that this is acceptable
column12: but should  probably be informed in reference documentation. One might also consider removing those Traits from ServiceManager...'"

column10: b"b' This pull request [fails]url  (merged c0410fc6 into 02f88daf).'"
b"b' This pull request [fails]url  (merged 792ad49a into 02f88daf).'"
b'b" I tried to be more specific in what losses there are when serializing  chain.  I don\'t know if these are acceptable losses.  With this solution
column11: chains should be serialized only if:a) the plugins are not needed after unserialization (e.g. one doesn\'t call ) ORb) the default plugin manager instance is used (it\'s OK if the property plugins is reseted on wakeup)"'

column10: b"b' This pull request [passes]url  (merged 9d18f884 into 02f88daf).'"
b'b" I looked into the code in both FilterChain and ValidatorChain. In each
column11: even if you add the filter or validator by name
column12: an instance is immediately pulled from the attached plugin manager
column13: and then attached to the chain. What this means is that we always have a fully populated chain. My worry in applying this change is that developers will see that the objects composing filter chains and validator chains are serializable
column14: and then think that the filter and validator chains are serialized as part of the process -and then they\'ll wonder why validation breaks after deserializing such an object. What I\'m suggesting is that we should likely look at a more robust solution that allows the attached plugins to be serialized with the chains."'

column10: b'b\' "What I\\\'m suggesting is that we should likely look at a more robust solution that allows the attached plugins to be serialized with the chains." Actually
column11: the attached plugins (if you mean validator and filter instances and not property \\\'plugins\\\') ARE serialized with the chain
column12: but the plugin manager is not. In my first post
column13: with the initial pull request
column14: I said that the plugins are lost. What I meant by that
column15: is that plugin manager is lost (property \\\'plugins\\\'). Anyway something is lost and I\\\'d like to see a more robust solution myself. Serializing plugin manager may be impossible though...\''

column10: b"b' [WIP help] Allow to remove decimals in CurrencyFormat'"

b'b\' This PR adds an option to CurrencyFormat view helper to remove the two decimals number (I often need to simply prints the integer number). HOWEVER it looks like NumberFormatter has a bug (I tried to read the unit tests of PHP and none of them covered the case
column11: and I have not been able to find any help anywhere on the Internet). The problem is that depending on the locale
column12: it does not remove the decimals digits. This option sets the NumberFormatter::FRACTION_DIGITS attribute to 0
column13: which should remove the decimals. For instance
column14: when setting the locale to "en_US"
column15: this $numberFormatter->formatCurrency(\\\'45\\\'
column16: \\\'USD\\\') prints "$45". However
column17: when keeping the same locale (en-US) but chaning the currency to \\\'EUR\\\'
column18: it prints "\\xe2\\x82\\xac45.00". At the same time
column19: if I change the locale to "fr-FR"
column20: and prints a number with currency "EUR"
column21: it prints 45 \\xe2\\x82\\xac
column22: and thus removing the decimals. I\\\'ve tried the money_format function of PHP and it does not suffer from this problem. So it really looks like Intl implementation is buggy
column26: it just does nothing. So we may merge (or not ?). If anyone have some thoughts about it... (side note : rounding the number before formatting does nothing).\''

column10: b"b' [2.1] ServiceManager tagging support'"

b'b" The current implementation allows only N names (aliases) for 1 service. This PR adds the ability to add 1 name (tag) for N services or aliases. It is basicly a bag of services.  The current implementation won\'t check if a service or an alias exists before inserting it into the tag bag nor does it ensure that a service is unique in the bag
column11: because that would require a more complex implementation which would decrease the performance of the  . **Example:**  "'

column10: b'b\' What\\\'s the use case for this? And since the tags can be added in arbitrary order
column11: I assume this would be for something like a set of plugins or hooks? The implementation is certainly clean enough -I\\\'m just not sure when someone would  to use this. It also means that ServiceManager has additional API methods that ServiceLocatorInterface does not define
column12: and which developers would start to rely on -which tells me we likely need a "TaggableInterface" or similar. Could you outline the use cases here
column13: and perhaps write a post to the zf-contributors mailing list discussing the new feature in order to solicit feedback? Thanks in advance!\''

column10: b'b" One use case would be ZendDeveloperTools. Currently you have to register collectors and matchers directly with the module and the module would utilize the service manager to retrive the instances for the registered objects. With tags I would be able to remove that step and just ask the service manager for a specific tag. You are right about the additional API methods -something like a interface would be a good idea. I\'ll add one once I\'m home."'
b'b" To go into detail about the ZendDeveloperTools use case -which also applies to every other module that supports any kind of plug-ins. The question is
column11: how to handle plug-ins in modules. Some possible solutions:Use some kind of module specific registry to register the FQCN or a service name.Run a module specific bootstrap event
column12: so you can register the plug-in directly. Add a new service listener and let it create a dedicated service manager. This method has some drawbacks:  It increases the complexity of the installtion and uninstallation process and will break the application or module if wasn\'t done right.  Depending on how many modules using this method
column13: it will create a _(noteable)_ impact on the application (bootstrap) performance. I could create a benchmark for that case if requested. Service tagging is just one solution and I added it because I\'m accustomed to the idea of tagging from Symfony. But as you said
column14: it creates a new API which is not compatible with the  . "'

column10: b'b" Closed
column11: because no matter how you look at it I don\'t thing it justifies adding a new
column12: incompatible
column13: API just to reduce some sort of module configuration."'

b"b' [Enhancement] Add an easier way to use i18n view helpers.'"
b'b" hi
column11: sorry for my bad English. I have 2 issues. If I use the translate helper :  and the translator is not set
column12: it will throw an exception. I am trying to make a reusable modules.When I make French websites
column13: I need the translatorBut if I want to make English websites
column14: I don\'t need it.I guess the exception here is unnecessary. The second issue
column15: is the use of TextDomain. I use one textDomain per modules
column16: each module embed translation files. If I want to generate a Form for example
column17: I need to write And if I use partials
column18: the textdomain may be overwritten by another script. I come with an idea : Why don\'t use another helper as Proxy.   On each scripts
column19: we use pushTranslatorTextDomain and popTranslatorTextDomain to ensure there will not have any conflict if we use partial. What do you think about that? I don\'t know if it can be PR."'

column10: b'b\' @coolmic for both your problems there are good alternatives. First
column11: usually you have translations for all your locales. It is a good practice to write all message "to-be-translated" as English sentences
column12: but you translate these at all times
column13: nevertheless of the default locale. There is no need to check if the language is English and then omit the translation. Translators also give usually the key back as translation when it does not exist. So if you want to translate \\\'hello\\\'
column14: you have a French translation \\\'hello\\\' =The second problem: it is in most cases easier to translate the labels directly in the form class itself. Your form looks something like this: Every label is translated inside the form
column15: so you can make your form view very simple: If you match two forms you get form two different modules (and thus
column16: two different text domains)
column17: you have no trouble in doing so. \''

column10: b'b" Yeah
column11: the first one is not really an issue
column12: I just want to avoid to instanciate the translator object
column13: but it\'s probably an unnecessary optimization. For the second one
column14: the translation will be done 2 times
column15: and for formElementsErrors
column16: it\'s an hassle with
column17: because I have to translate each template message for each validator. Well
column18: the main purpose of this ticket is to have feedbacks about the TranslatorProxy."'

column10: b"b' Zendframework 2 controller plugins problem'"

b"b' I have written a controller plugin like this: As you can see i have passed a variable to my view. but this variable is not accessible in my view script using the following command: $this->MyVariable'"
b'b" @rahimasgari the only thing you did is you created a view model. You did not assign any view variables to the view renderer. In that aspect
column11: zf2 differs much from zf1. Let\'s assume a basic controller looks like this: Now
column12: controller plugins just help you not to repeat yourself. If you have 20 actions which instantiate a view model and assign this value to this variable you might use a controller plugin. The _result of the plugin is captured in the controller_: As you see
column13: you still need to return the view model in the controller yourself."'

column10: b"b' @juriansluiman setVariables method of ViewModel class instance just do the job. But it also doesnt work with the way that you suggested .'"
b"b' @rahimasgari I gave an answer to your first question. This is not a real issue
column11: since you confuse many different things in zf2. You work with a view **model** not a view **renderer**. They are completely different. SetVariables is just a setter where a constructor argument can do the same. A view model is in that sense just a value object
column12: nothing more. And I am pretty sure this way works
column13: since I have used it in my projects. '"

column10: b"b' @juriansluiman so maybe the problem is that i havent called the controller plugin from within my controller action directly. I have written an event listener which calls the controller plugin. Here is the code:  '"
b'b" The point Jurian is making is that you need to return the view model from your controller either that
column11: or assign it to the event\'s result property. Returning it from the plugin is not sufficient.  For instance
column12: try this from your controller: This would return the view model returned by the plugin. "'

column13: but got the following error: PHP Fatal error:  Uncaught exception \'Zend\\\\Http\\\\Exception\\\\RuntimeException\' with message \'Error parsing body doesn\'t seem to be a chunked message\' in /-:449Stack trace:#0 /-(303): Zend\\\\Http\\\\Response->decodeChunkedBody(\'<zendServerAPIR...\')#1 /(32): Zend\\\\Http\\\\Response->getBody()#2 /(146): ZendService\\\\ZendServerAPI\\\\Adapter\\\\DumpParser->parse(NULL)#3 /(296): ZendService\\\\ZendServerAPI\\\\Method\\\\Method->parseResponse()#4 /(60): ZendService\\\\ZendServerAPI\\\\Request->send()#5 /(9): ZendService\\\\ZendServerAPI\\\\Jobqueue->jobqueueJobsList()#6 {main}  thrown in /on line 449 "'

column10: b"b' I will see if i can resolve this issue this evening'"
b"b' Reverting this line solves my issue too. The reason seem to be
column11: that deocdeChunkedBody is called via getBody in the response. At that time
column12: it needs the chunk line to determinate the size. But if this line is removed via the socket adapter
column13: that will always fail (decodeChunkedBody in \\\\Zend\\\\Http\\\\Response):  '"

column10: b'b\' I came across the following in this morning: If automatically decodes chunked responses
column11: why not have behave the same way (i.e.
column12: the way it has since 2.0.6)?  It seems to me that there are two possible solutions:1. have remove the "Transfer-Encoding" header (like does)
column13: or 2. have both adapters leave the Transfer-Encoding header alone
column14: not attempt a second decoding in
column15: and deprecate  .\''

column10: b'b\' There is a fix for the Zend\\\\Http\\\\Client\\\\Adapter\\\\Socket has also been reported #3267 The Error occurred with @66f269f reverting this commit "fixes" the error in regards to chunked body. Not sure what the fix was meant for or if this was intended or not.\''
b'b\' @BinaryKitten @weierophinney The fix (i.e.
column11: #3169) was meant to solve this issue (#3036) as well as #3143. In both those cases
column12: was invoked when would have been more appropriate.  When special encoding ("chunked"
column13: gzip
column14: or "deflate") is not used
column15: and return the same result. Compounding the risk of confusion
column16: the automatically decodes chunked responses and strips out the "Transfer-Encoding" header
column17: making it even more likely that and will return the same result. My earlier suggestions notwithstanding
column18: I think reverting to the pre-PR #3169 behavior is probably the best course of action. @sachitsac and I will just have to update our code to use getBody like we should have in the first place. \''

column10: b"b' Writing session to table on request close fails over multiple servers'"
b'b\' Scenario: Same user
column11: same browser
column12: sends multiple ajax requests to the server at the same time. Requests are being balanced by a load balancer
column13: and sent to multiple servers
column14: with the same database as storage. Error: "PHP Fatal Error: Exception thrown without a stack frame in Unknown on line 0" very helpful of course Issue: The code that finds the session in the database and updates or inserts it is not doing this in one go. Problem is
column15: that anywhere between the find and insert
column16: other servers might have already inserted that session
column17: resulting this particular request to fail
column18: with a real error message of: Duplicate entry on primary key "$session id". My solution for the time being was to wrap this up in a database transaction
column19: but all that code there should translate into something like: and let the adapter(mysql
column20: postgres
column21: oracle
column22: whatever) decide what the best method of inserting or updating is. For example
column24: most probably an INSERT () ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE would be the best solution.\''

column10: b"b' I believe this to be related to: #2628 '"
b"b' This is not closed
column11: as this is not the correct way to close it. It is not a destruction problem
column12: but an insert concurrent problem as described.'"

column10: b"b' Sorry; did not realize that i had misread this one.  '"

b'b" I believe the best way to handle this one is to check for the exception on the primary key value; if that is raised then we should attempt again with an update; i\'ll give this one an update either tonight or tomorrow."'
b'b" @mwillbanks wouldn\'t a transaction be more best suited for this? Usually update or insert processes should be done in 1 go
column11: not more."'

column10: b'b" A transaction in this case actually wouldn\'t help any....beginTransaction()read...insert...commit(); say another request did that from the time the read happened; it would still have the same issue.  A transaction will not actually lock the row; also taking an explicit lock sometimes helps but could also cause other issues (and may not work in all database types).  "'

column10: b"b' Add RBAC support for navigation helper.'"
b"b' Permissions-based navigation support for RBAC component.'"
b'b" Mixing the two permissions systems into the same objects is... strange :/. As I told it on another issue
column11: Zend\\\\Navigation should be agnostic to any permission system. Check @spiffyjr implementation (this should have been the Zend\\\\Navigation of ZF 2 but because of lack of time it wasn\'t integrated
column12: but it shoudl for ZF 3): url  And modules like ZfcRbac or BjyAuthorize will integrate the navigation to Rbac or Acl. I think this is a better idea than mixing. But as Zend\\\\Navigation is a bit broken
column13: may be we can afford this for ZF 2."'

column10: b"b' @bakura10I am on your side. It is a bad idea to add extra methods for any permission system.'"
b'b\' The problem is is that there needs to be an "integrated" solution for the RBAC component. Otherwise
column11: I would argue that the RBAC component should not have been included in the "core" of the framework. It\\\'s unreasonable to expect that users not assume that there be some level of integration between the RBAC component and navigation. It\\\'s not the cleanest solution to be sure but it is one that works. Is there a better alternative maybe? \''

column10: b'b\' I use the ZfcRbac module myself. I don\\\'t know that there would be a way to provide any integration from the ZfcRbac component itself unless you are proposing that the module include an alternative to the current implementation of the ZF2 Navigation component. This is the most flexible solution I have found so far but I am absolutely 100% open to a better alternative. This is how I go about things in my own application: (where "rbacHelper" is "ZfcRbac\\\\Service\\\\Rbac") This way
column11: you\\\'re not coupling Navigation directly to the ZfcRbac module while still being able to leverage the power of the ZfcRbac module.  \''

column10: b'b\' Assuming that Acl has and Rbac has
column11: I think a good alternative would be to inject into the Page a "permission callable" that simply must return a boolean telling if the user has access to the Page.This is a generic way that will work with all permission systems. Thoughts?\''

column10: b'b\' I don\\\'t think this is an appropriate solution; what happens if we add more permissions systems
column11: each with their own APIs and requirements for determining validation? A better approach is to trigger an event -let\\\'s call it "isAllowed" -passing the page to the event; a listener can then return a boolean value indicating this status. This allows keeping the actual mechanism for determining rights separate from the navigation itself
column12: while still providing the ability to provide access-specific navigation to users. @francisdaigle do you want to revise this PR to do that? or would you like somebody else to tackle it?\''

b"b' I believe that this was due to a session that was previously created; all new sessions should not show this issue. I believe that we can make a change to allow anything that is Traversable that does not have any harmful side effects.'"

column11:
Tlapi" notifications@ wrote:\''
zendframework	3880	closed	34	JulianPrice	2013-02-23 19:28:27	525.85			+1	b'b" Including the autoloader pulls all your ZF2 application\'s plugins into your other php app, which you probably don\'t need.  It increases the overhead and the probability of a conflict such as duplicate function names.  The same goes for your Zend application configuration you probably don\'t need it in your other php app. Here is a Wordpress plugin which pulls in just the ZF2 library, which is enough to allow ZF2 and Wordpress to play together nicely and share the session without breaking it.  Copy the following to wp-, set $zend_library_path, and enable the plugin in Wordpress Admin.  "'
zendframework	3880	closed	35	Ocramius	2013-02-23 19:28:27	532.67			+1	b'b" An autoloader itself (composer\'s) does not bring any noticeable overhead... Even if configured with 800 dependencies :)"'
zendframework	3880	closed	36	JulianPrice	2013-02-23 19:28:27	560.67	+1			b'b" The issue for me was the conflicts I\'m using a 3rd party ZF2 module with a function that conflicted with Wordpress core.  Generally speaking, eliminating the modules removes an unknown factor from the equation and results in a solution that should work for more people. I guessed my solution would be more efficient but I didn\'t profile it.  If you\'ve bothered to set up a classmap then I guess my solution would be less efficient, although it could probably me modified to use a classmap."'

column10: b'b" @ralphschindler I\'ve been doing a lot of thinking about whether or not these factories should be in the individual components
column11: or in or  . It\'s not unlikely that a developer will want to use the factories outside of the MVC system. If we have the factories in
column12: the developer then either had to add that component as a dependency
column13: or write their own factories. This makes a great argument for having the factories in either the components or in  . My inclination is to make them part of the components:The factories serve as some documentation as to how to instantiate a component  classes in the component
column14: particularly in how to wire up dependencies.While the factories are defined by the component
column15: they could potentially be consumed by another service locator  IoC system easily.Because you do not _need_ to use the factories
column16: the dependency on is an optional one. Developers would only need to add it if they choose to use the factories. As such
column17: I plan to merge this to the develop branch for 2.2.0."'

column10: b"b' Delegate factories'"
b'b\' I\\\'ve been working on this concept for some time
column11: but this is basically a cleaned up version of #2995 ## Why do we need this? The idea is to be able to build [delegates]url  of any existing service. This can be used to build "decorators" for service instantiation and for proxying.#### Delegation Imagine that you have a and a object. A wraps around a "real" instance like following
column12: but provides additional API that sends queries to a logger: Currently
column13: our problem is that such a wrapper requires us to completely re-define the factory that instantiates  . There\\\'s no way to re-use logic from such a factory. We have to rewrite it and be aware of its internal logic:  #### Proxying We can proxy any service (with the assumption that we know its class name or implemented interface) and make it "lazy"
column14: so that its dependencies don\\\'t get instantiated when we request them. This allows us to build lightweight containers
column15: as explained in url  Also
column16: we don\\\'t have to worry about how the original service is instantiated
column17: since the original factory is still existing.## Example In the following example
column18: I\\\'ve simply replaced the original service (instance of  ) with a new one that contains the original service in property  :  ## Implementation flawsAdditional method call to
column19: since I splitted to allow this kind of behavioris public
column20: since I cannot use a closure and call in PHP 5.3It may not be clear at first
column21: but the delegate factory is a service (which is a huge advantage
column22: but is a bit different from what we\\\'re used to see)## Documentation A documentation PR has been provided at -documentation#825\''

column10: b"b' Actually
column11: the factory does not produce delegates
column12: but delegators
column13: as explained in url  I will change this after having prepared the docs PR.'"

column10: b"b' Date format not respected in LessThan and GreaterThan validators'"

b'b\' The date format of form elements are not taken into account when a form is validated with min and max attribute. This is because the LessThan and GreaterThan validators compare strings. When I set the format for my Date element to \\\'d-m-Y\\\' and set max attribute to "01-01-2001"my input "10-01-2000" will return an error: 10-01-2000 < 01-01-2001 returns false\''
b"b' Those validators are not meant for date comparisons.'"
b"b' Exactly. But they are used inside / as validators:url '"
b"b' Oh
column11: that is clearly a bug then.'"

column10: b'b" This is a hard one
column11: as the return value of is what is passed to the validator chain. Since by default
column12: that\'s the formatted string
column13: comparisons will likely not work as expected; ideally
column14: we should be comparing the timestamps. The only way I can think of to manage this is to create a custom Input type for date  time types which will ensure the timestamp is used. However
column15: this will also likely require changes to the various date and time elements so that returns a object. As such
column16: I\'m postponing the issue to 2.3.0
column17: as we need time to work out a reasonable solution."'

column10: b"b' Possibly related to url '"
b"b' Releated: url '"
b'b\' Doing a little more investigation today. More problematic than expected:can return any of: a instance
column11: a formatted  string
column12: or a timestamp.As a form element
column13: the likelihood of having a instance present is next to nil.The only filter related to  values is
column14: which will cast the value to a string
column15: based on the format registered with it. About the only way I see this working at this point is if you do one of the following:Right now
column16: if you specify a format for the element of "u" or "U"
column17: and also add a DateTimeFormatter filter for the element that uses that format
column18: the current validators should "just work
column19:
as they will be comparing integer strings.As for a future fix, we could add the DateTimeFormatter filter by default to the input specification, using the same format string as is registered with the element. This would attempt to munge the value into a formatted  string. This would only work for comparison purposes if using the "u" or "U" formats, however.Alternately, we could add Form-specific validators that would cast the values to DateTime instances before doing the necessary  ,  , and step validations, but ultimately leave the value of the input untouched. This seems more tricky, but probably more correct. Eventually, we will want to make GreaterThan and LessThan work with DateTime and other built-ins. However, I think the crux of the problem, as reported here, has more to do with the DateTime form element, and requires a different approach, as outlined above. @maxnuf @localheinz @ThaDafinser @DASPRiD -thoughts?\''
zendframework	4440	closed	8	maxnuf	2013-05-07 17:36:50	1219.78		+1		b'b" Using the DateTimeFormatter does help, but only for the date formats that the \\\\DateTime parser understands. won\'t work. I think an EarlierThan and LaterThan Validator that cast values to DateTime based on a specified format is a more clear approach."'
zendframework	4440	closed	9	weierophinney	2013-05-07 17:36:50	277.28		+1		b"b' Postponing to 2.4.0, as this will require a fair number of additions and changes to accomplish.'

column10: b"b' OpenSSL options handling inadequate in Socket'"
b'b\' In
column11: default options are: In practice
column12: along with "timeout" and "keepalive"
column13: these are the only options the code uses.  But the actual list of options supported for SSL are url  : 1. verify_peer 2. allow_self_signed 3. cafile 4. capath 5. local_cert 6. passphrase 7. CN_match 8. verify_depth 9. ciphers 10. capture_peer_cert 11. capture_peer_cert_chain 12. SNI_enabled 13. SNI_server_name There is no good reason Zend users should be blocked from using verify_depth
column14: for example.  More specifically
column15: there is no good reason Socket should _allow_ them to set it (or _anything_) via setOptions() and then silently _do nothing_ with it. The arbitrary remapping of ourkey =\''

column10: b'b" Something like this is more appropriate and doesn\'t require ongoing maintenance as the underlying library adds
column11: removes or changes options: A similar argument can be made regarding the option sets of HTTP
column12: FTP
column13: etc. "'

column10: b"b' I certainly agree with you that it should not silently ignore options that are not implement by the framework
column11: as to your suggested solution
column12: i see nothing wrong with it. '"

column10: b'b" The main difficulty is the inertia against breaking backwards compatibility. I understand the (somewhat deprecated) Zend naming conventions regarding underscores for methods and classes
column11: but -correct me if I\'m wrong -there is no restriction against underscores in keys inside argument arrays.  The remapping of these options seems to be in part from applying the old conventions in the wrong place."'

b'b" So first of i want to say dam you @bakura10 for creating so many awesome PR i feel i need to do something... So the idea grew a bit in the # channel today about the performance of various components e.g ServiceManger
column11: EventManager and Stdlib. And how we could increase the performance of these components. Something we realised is that many of the components are rather . So maintaining the code **shouldn\'t** be too much of a hasel to maintain either (Famous last words).  So my idea is to start writing the EventManager in Zephir first to see how much of a performance boost we get and see what issues are with using it."'

column10: b'b" This is an even more exciting issue than everything I could have made. Let\'s be clear about Zephir: according to them it\'s still an alpha so let\'s just wait a bit to see how this thing evolves. But it\'s indeed interesting. The questions are: 1) Are we able to maintain in sync two components (one in pure PHP

b"b' [WIP] [ZF3] Validators refactoring'"
b'b" Hi everyone
column11: Again another  for ZF3. I promise
column12: this is the last one I will make (ok
column13: maybe Forms too :D...). This one is another lower-level component
column14: but I need this one to correctly finish the InputFilter one. As for filter
column15: the main changes will be: some performance optimizations we can make with PHP 5.4
column16: cleaning some code
column17: homogenize options by using underscore_separated... The only real change I\'ve made for now is to make the ValidatorChain exactly the same as FilterChain (I was always bothered that those classes didn\'t have the same method names or underlying implementation). HOWEVER
column18: there is a change @ocramius and I discussed on IRC and I\'d love to have your opinion on that. The InputFilter refactor made the component completely stateless. It opened interesting optimizations
column19: and the idea came to make validators also stateless. To stay simple
column20: the following code: Will be transformed to: As for input filters
column21: validationResult instances are serializable and can be transformed to JSON. Translation would still be handled by the validators themselves: they will translate the error messages and pass them to the validation result. What do you think of this idea? Is there any drawback that you may see from it? EDIT : Credit for the idea to George url "'

column10: b'b" Note: as discussed on IRC (if you are reading this and are not on IRC
column11: then the question is why you aren\'t!)
column12: translations can be handled in a very different way. Having the translator within the validation component is quite problematic
column13: so what we can do is having an error translator that works like following: Look ma! Validators don\'t know about translations anymore! Eventually
column14: a _may_ implement logic to ease access to patterns or context variables needed by the translator. That interface doesn\'t necessarily cause a dependency to the component."'

column10: b'b" That\'s pure genius."'
b'b\' ping @Ocramius and @weierophinney  I\\\'ve made a proof of concept with the Between validator. There are multiple things I\\\'ve made that we need to talk about.First
column11: the AbstractValidator is now very lightweight compared to [previously]url  It has no reference to any Translator
column12: no data to store. I\\\'ve also removed the static "minimumLength" variable because I think it\\\'s the job of a view helper to cut a message.Validators are completely decoupled from translation layer.All variables were changed from camelCased to underscore_separated as it is by convention.Please note the "setOptions" thing. This pattern goes beyond the Validator class. A LOT of classes inside a framework needs that kind of thing (an option array). I think that we can make it really convenient in ZF3 by writing a trait (like my previous PR @weierophinney :)) that could be used in all those classes. Of course
column13: this trait would make some assumptions : that keys are underscore_separated
column14: and that the setter of the corresponding property is called to set the value (this thing should propably take into account isser and has
column15: until we have real property accessors in PHP :(). Of course
column16: custom needs can avoid the use of the trait
column17: but I think that would be a convenient pattern if we really follow the same covnentions accross the framework. We could even write an interface like "OptionsCapableInterface
column18: that a factory could check and inject options.The validator classes are no longer responsible to create error messages. They just create a ValidationResult object with error messages
column19: data and optional variables that can be injected inside the message.The Validation error have three main methods: isValid
column20: getRawErrorMessages and getErrorMessages. When getErrorMessages is called
column21: variables are being replaced using a preg_replace. The getRawErrorMessages can be used by for translation. For instance
column26: if we want to keep it simple
column27: the dependency to i18n could be moved to the ValidationResult (which is probably better
column28: as some people may be angry if we introduce anothr abstraction level). What do you think of this?\''

column11: the message variables are defined like this: It is assumed that the validator has a property called "min". Still abut convention
column12: we need to know if
column13: in a message template
column14: we prefer this: OR: I\\\'d argue that it makes more sense to use camelCased in string.\''

column10: b'b" @bakura10 This is looking great! I\'d argue we wouldn\'t need _any_ i18n awareness in Validator after this. It would be up to the developer  a view helper to take the ValidationResult and use the data it contains to create translated messages. This approach would offer a cleaner separation of concerns. Since you already define the ability to get the messages as well as the message variables
column11: this should be trivial to accomplish."'

column10: b"b' Thanks. The only thing that bother me currently is how to handle the specific case of ValidatorChain. How should the ValidationResult be used? Because
column11: by definition
column12: the validator chain may return multiple error messages per validators
column13: and multiple set of variables. If have no idea about how to do it. Should we have a specific ValidationResult (ValidationResultCollection) or other way using nested arrays?'"

column10: b"b' @bakura10 I would argue having a ValidationResult and a ValidationResultCollection
column11: which aggregates named ValidationResult and ValidationResultCollection instances; they should share a common interface that defines things like so that the developer can determine whether or not anything further needs to be done.  This allows developers to find the correctly named result in order to display individual validation messages
column12: and also allows arbitrary nesting.'"

column10: b'b" @texdc : I\'ve made some more work today: url  So now for serialization
column11: I save the data
column12: message variables and raw error messages (to be able to recreate the object). On the other hand
column13: for jsonSerializable

column10: b'b" I think you\'re missing the point of a dedicated result class.  It should be extremely light-weight to facilitate messaging.  Adding data is out-of-scope and unnecessary because the data is available before validation.  Message building should (still) be handled by the validator
column11: not the result.  The result should only contain ready-to-be-consumed messages.  "'

column10: b'b" @texdc the result is just a value. Translating it happens somewhere in a  . It\'s an immutable packet of data containing all what is necessary to assemble relevant bits of sentences for validation errors (to me). The submitted data can be part of the packet in my opinion..."'
b'b" Isn\'t that the case in my implementation? I agree that data **may** be removed from the ValidationResult (well
column11: the problem is for people that would like to include the value inside the error message during interpolation). However I don\'t agree with you on another point: the validator should not create the error messages itself and do the interpolation. Otherwise you miss the whole advantage of being able to separate i18n component from the validator. As the ValidationResult contains message variables AND raw error messages
column12: a ValidationResultTransaltor can now be used to translate all the messages."'

column10: b'b" @Ocramius right
column11: but the data is not necessary and weighs the result down. @bakura10 The value can be included in the messages when they\'re generated by the validator.  If the validator doesn\'t generate messages then it should just return a boolean and let a message generator populate the result."'

column10: b"b' Having said this
column11: I think it even makes sense to remove the data from ValidationResult (so we only stay with raw error message and message variables
column12: the only thing that are needed to create error messages). What do you think @Ocramius ?'"

column10: b'b" @texdc : so you\'re assuming the translation still happen in validator as it is now
column11: while I saw the biggest advantage of this specific result class to allow complete separatin of concenrs."'

column10: b"b' @texdc : storing raw error messages and message variables in this validation result class allows you to do this: If the validator is still responsible of doing the interpolation
column11: you cannot do that anymore.'"

column10: b'b" @bakura10 I\'m still not sure about that. One thing is for sure to It\'s just a text serialization (human readable) of a validation failure. Serializing a Validation result to human readable text is not happening in the validator (or shouldn\'t). As for the data I\'m not sure. I don\'t see that much of a problem to send data around. If it\'s a burden
column11: you could always strip it."'

column10: b'b" @bakura10 The point is SoC.  Translators should act on text.  A validator or a result should be oblivious to a translator.  Isn\'t translation a view concept? @Ocramius beat me to it."'

b'b\' I agree with you @Ocramius . After all my implementation of ValidationResult is really lightweight. I agree with you that I could remove the errorMessages completely from the object (I just did it for caching purpose but well... not sure many people will call "getErrorMessages" severla times :o. @texdc : you\\\'re the one not wanting SoC here =)...\''

b'b" Having the data in the validation result makes it a nice serializable package that is very simple to use and guarantees immutability. I wouldn\'t change that for the sake of performance (which isn\'t that big problem unless you transfer huge amounts of validation errors over network). So here\'s a recap:1. validator gets data and builds a package (validationResult) of + + (or whatever is needed to identify the kind of failures
column11: if any)2. some kind of logic (external to the validationResult or in specific types of validationResult) interpolates the errors and allows getting human readable versions3. smartass i18n component allows to use + + to build smartass translated messages in whatever silly language they use in your region"'

column10: b'b" And if I\'m validating a data import of 10
column11: 000\'s of datapoints?  How then would adding the values not be a performance issue?"'

column10: b'b" @texdc just use a custom validation result object that ignores any passed in data. You don\'t want to build an error message with those 10k points anyways
column11: so you can just ignore the passed in value and discard it."'

column10: b'b" That\'s backwards.  A base interface wouldn\'t have the data.  It\'s a feature that you\'d add when necessary  ."'
b'b" Valid point @texdc . In fact the question is that: when would you need to have the value? I mean
column11: the refactor of Input filter store the values BECAUSE you need it (you need to have the filtered value). In the case of validator
column12: it\'s pretty useless because you have the value when you validate it. And you can be assured it won\'t be changed after the validator is run. The only use case I see is when you want to interpolate the actual value in the error message. But this has been removed some time ago in the framework for security reason."'

column10: b'b" @texdc I understand your concerns there
column11: but it\'s an edge case. Having more data always allows you to discard data in between. Having less data by default forces you to find ways to retrieve data. The big plus here is immutability. Since the interface of the ValidationResult would probably only have getters (not sure how it\'s now
column12: since I\'m not really up to read code right now)
column13: you\'re pretty sure that you\'re working with a safe data packet."'

column10: b"b' @texdc nah
column11: simply returning would be fine IMO'"

column10: b"b' again
column11: this is not what I intended.  if you want data in your result
column12: extend it.'"

column10: b'b" Additionally
column11: I don\'t want to land in duck-typing land
column12: where we implicitly upcast everything at runtime :) That\'s always a nasty scenario. Including the data is a nice default in my opinion
column13: and since data is data
column14: you can always simply remove it"'

column10: b'b" In order to get my head around this issue
column11: I\'m writing some things up. Hopefully it clarifies. The only difference regarding attaching InputFilter defaults between 2.2.3 and 2.2.4 is the default value
column12: which is **false** for the first and **true** for the latter. So with 2.2.3 the defaults are attached **only when** the InputFilter has a filter for the current element
column13: which is strange behavior. So it makes sense the way it is with 2.2.4: The defaults are attached **unless** the InputFilter has a filter for the current element. Both in 2.2.3 and in 2.2.4 any filters defined by the the  implementing are added after."'

column10: b"b' Verified that has no effect at this point.'"
b"b' Also verified that changing from to in the test case does not make a difference.'"
b'b\' Okay
column11: tracked it down
column12: and it has to do with  . Essentially
column13: we have an order-of-operations issue
column14: and I don\\\'t see a way we can resolve it. When you add an input to the input filter that already exists
column15: the method grabs the original
column16: and calls using the input that was passed in. In the case of your test
column17: you\\\'re doing the following:Adding a element
column18: which is itself an  .Creating a instance with an instance corresponding to the defined
column19: and attaching it directly to the form.Implicitly calling via
column20: which fetches the explicitly attached instance
column21: iterates through all elements
column22: and then adds inputs when any are instances. This in turn invokes the operation defined above
column23: as it is trying to add the input specification from the element to the already existing you explicitly created. If we set the flag
column24: what happens is that never attempts to merge in the element\\\'s input specification. The problem that now exists is that we decided with #4996 that the expected merge order should be to merge new elements into old ones. This is intuitive and expected -what we had before was not. However
column26: the order of operations becomes more dicey -if you set the element first
column27: and then add an input filter
column28: which one is the "new" instance? That said: I would _expect_ that explicitly adding the input filter instance will be problematic
column29: knowing the merge order is from new into old
column30: and knowing that the input specifications are merged when the input filter is retrieved. To confirm my suspicions
column31: I tried altering the patch to not explicitly add the input filter: This worked perfectly. Alternately
column32: this also worked: My point is: instead of adding an explicit input filter instance
column33: could you define a fieldset  form as an
column34: instead? This would preserve the merge operations
column35: as the input filter would be created on first access instead
column36: and input filters take precedence over individual inputs.  At this point
column37: I don\\\'t think there\\\'s any way we can accommodate the assumptions of this test explicitly
column38: regardless of whether or not you see it as a BC break; the change made in #4996 was definitely correct to make; the previous behavior was unfortunately a side effect of broken behavior.\''

column10: b'b" ### Why can\'t I specify TTL ? Since I remember working with code-level cache solutions there was always an easy method to specify TTL on per-item basis. It is a [common]url  [feature]url  [among]url  most well-known libraries and extensions and was present in [ZF1 Zend_Cache]url  Sadly
column11: zf2 is missing this.  ### Problem 1 ZF2 Cache Storage does not allow to store items with specific TTL. The first problem was missing parameter in all [Cache\\\\StorageInterface]url  write methods (i.e.
column12: etc.). Without this
column13: the only way to set an item with a specific TTL was:  ### Problem 2 Unfortunately
column14: the above code does not work properly. This is because many ZF2 adapters do not support or understand item-level TTL
column15: unless it is handled internally by the backend (i.e. natively supports TTL and it\'s getting fed with the one from options). For example
column16: and would exhibit unexpected behavior when discarding old items or fetching items if we tried to manipulate ttl:  ### The goal  ### Solution[x] Add support to StorageInterface.[x] Refactor to handle $ttl in write operations.[x] Pass on to listeners (plugins).[x] Refactor all classes to use per-item and pass it on to underlying backend.[x] Refactor to support per-item TTL.[x] Refactor to support per-item TTL.[x] Add TTL tests that work with ad-hoc ttl setting.[x] Add overlapping temporal per-item ttl tests."'

column10: b'b" @Thinkscape Please start discussion before doing so much work.1. The caching component in ZF2 is designed to hold a cache storage instance per cachable group of items E.g. If you have products and users that should be cached you have two different cache storage instances each with it\'s own configuration and the TTL if part of the configuration2. The and adapters handles TTL correctly on reading items (using the current time
column11: the last modification time and the configured TTL) this behavior is marked by the capability entry   Your implementation slows down the filesystem adapter because it requires to read the file header from disk instead of simply check  3. As you should noted the adapter can\'t handle TTL in such a simple way that would require to store the expiration date together with the value. This would reduce compatibility to other systems using the same storage This would increase complexity by storing a complex data structure This would increase overhead even for cache configurations not needing expiry by TTL4. Unit tests checking TTL are available for all adapters at   url  url  url  ... What you suggest is to implement the same behavior for all caching adapters ... that should be done by a storage plugin. The second feature request is to add the TTL as part of the API but why you need it if you configure different caches for different groups of items. Why it\'s part of writing methods and not part of reading methods (As described above how TTL works on filesystem adapter)? Why you don\'t wont to add other options as part of the API (like the namespace)?"'

column11: a cache (/\\xcb\\x88k\\xc3\\xa6\\xca\\x83/ KASH)[1] is a component that transparently stores data so that future requests for that data can be served faster."url  Again a ** is part of the clearing strategy** and is **not natively supported** by all storages.Implementing it as such an argument for all storages adds overhead to the storage not only if a  is required. column12: it\'s always valid if found. (Not commenting on anything else at this time -just thought this should be noted.)"'

b'b\' @Thinkscape @Ocramius The options array argument was in my first version of the cache (ZF2) but this has been removed because:The array isn\\\'t a good structure to make thinks clear It needs a very good documentation and even takes time for developers to make it right.merging arrays together is very slowhard to debug if someone takes a typo or much more loss in performance to auto detect such mistakeschanging options can change storage behavior (capabilities) which can beak functionality:  An object requires a specific behavior and checks is by current capabilities it also can get notified if a capability will be changed -@Thinkscape :The TTL will be optional doesn\\\'t help storages not supporting a TTL as they have to respect a TTL. (Optional means to use a default value only). And **YES** there are storages not supporting TTL. The filesystem adapter currently supports TTL in the defined behavior of calculating it on read. It\\\'s not wrong because a TTL is a dynamic value. The from you called "Item based TTL" is only one possible implementation I would call it TTL based TTD as it defines a specific time-to-die calculated on the given TTL + the current time. There are two big issues with your performance argument:1. the biggest performance lost currently is the EM and not options2. saving 2 function calls (that do nothing than  a pointed value) on the one side and adding IO + complexity and reducing flexibility on storages not supporting on the other side doesn\\\'t make sense in my opinion my 2 cent\''

column10: b'b" If and how the adapter supports TTL is defined in the capabilities each adapter  . Your are right that the option ttl doesn\'t nothing on adapter not supporting it this is wrong and I already thought about it -You _can_ nearly copy the class by @Ocramius  . You only need to check if the given storage adapter supports  . And you _can_ write a plugin to add such functionality.  You are comparing  apples and oranges!   etc. writes to local memory. The adapter only write to network using the defined protocol to a remote storage (the server stores in memory but other implementation exists). The filesystem adapter (as the name says it) writes to the local filesystem this can be simple but it can also be a very fast

b"b' [SM] Fix AbstractServiceFactories with aliased services.'"

b'b" The point of **AbstractFactories** is to delegate creation of plethora of different services to a single factory. They receive the following arguments (per interface): Those arguments are used to determine what to create and return from the factory. For example
column11: [DoctrineModule]url  uses an [abstract factory to construct all doctrine namepaced components]url  by regex-parsing the name of the service.  The problem surfaces when trying to use **Aliases on services created by abstract factory**. ### Example We have 3 service classes associated with service names: | Service Name | Real class name  service-foo | Application\\\\Class\\\\Foo  service-bar | Application\\\\Class\\\\Bar  service-baz | Application\\\\Class\\\\Baz | .. and the following abstract factory Now when we try to retrieve a service with we will receive the following arguments: | Service Name | $name | $requestedName  service-foo | servicefoo | service-foo  service-bar | servicebar | service-bar  service-baz | servicebaz | service-baz |### What happens when we use aliases Now let\'s add some aliases this will result in the following parameter values: | Service Name | $name | $requestedName  Alias\\\\Foo | servicefoo | Alias\\\\Foo  Alias\\\\Bar | servicebar | Alias\\\\Bar  Alias\\\\Baz | servicebaz | Alias\\\\Baz | The now contains the name of the requested alias. This is not a bug per se
column12: because we could use it to create branching factories on alias names
column13: however our abstract factory will stop working.### Solution I\'ve modified ServiceManager to pass to the abstract factory methods
column14: so that we know the name of the original class before aliasing and canonization.  This is one of the ways we could use this in our factory: And parameter values will become: | Service Name | $name | $requestedName | $originalName  Alias\\\\Foo | servicefoo | Alias\\\\Foo | service-foo  Alias\\\\Bar | servicebar | Alias\\\\Bar | service-bar  Alias\\\\Baz | servicebaz | Alias\\\\Baz | service-baz |### What\'s changed The PR is fully backward compatible. I have not modified and the extra parameter is considered as optional for all internal SM methods. Existing factories work the same and require no changes. We will probably deprecate name canonization in ZF3 so this will no longer be needed
column15: however for 2.\\\\* there is full BC and allow for smarter abstract factories while remaining fully compatible with aliasing."'

column11: that test seems fine. However
column12: I dont agree with that merge
column13: because you\\\'re calling setObject(). That method is bind() extract() responsability. Once you bind your model object to the form
column14: it already calls setObject() and extract()
column15: that extract() call will handle all the nested setObject calls. It is only a matter of having the right hydrator in each fieldset. I\\\'ll agree with the second part
column16: target element needs to have an object and the right hydrator in order to be able to extract the values
column17: but not with the first
column18: since collections are always arrays and since they always receive the same type of data
column19: they don\\\'t need a hydrator.\''

column10: b'b" @fabiocarneiro I can see where you\'re coming from but the and calls go hand in hand. The and process comes after. This is especially true for nested fieldsets
column11: where you\'re not binding to anything explicitly and the nested calls have to handle that case. Let\'s take an example. Say we have a entity which has a **product** property. This **product** property is supposed to contain a entity. But when we first create a shop
column12: we haven\'t set a entity yet. So
column13: when we bind this entity to the
column14: the inside doesn\'t have anything to bind to. But we need an object to hydrate and return where is it going to get this object? In comes  . Now the fieldset can hydrate a brand new entity unless the call from the form attaches an existing object to the fieldset."'

column10: b'b" You\'re right. That\'s true for the default object in the fieldset. I forgot i call setHydrator(...)->setObject(new ...) in my fieldsets
column11: but since this is a test
column12: it isn\'t possible to do like that."'

column10: b'b" @Ocramius my only concern is that if this BC doesn\'t get reverted (it was on a bugfix release) then all our forms have to use the Service Manager to pull in dependencies
column11: rather than being able to pass them through Factories. I know it\'s an often debated topic
column12: but everywhere else (Controllers for example)
column13: it\'s always recommended to pass in dependencies via () methods
column14: rather than passing in a Service Manager and then litter the class with $sm->get(\'Blah\\\\Blah\'). Our Forms have a couple of dependencies on other classes
column15: so we use the Factories to set them up. If the FormElementManager can\'t correctly initialize peered classes (as Custom Elements are a function of the FormElementManager)
column16: then the FormElementManager shouldn\'t be peered."'

column10: b'b" @al3xdm what\'s the reason for these elements to be in peered service managers? Why are they not registered directly with the form element manager?"'
b'b" The custom elements are registered with the FormElementManager
column11: it\'s the Form itself that is loaded via a peered Service Manager"'

column10: b'b" @al3xdm how about moving the forms to the FormElementManager then? They\'d still be available
column11: just not via peering."'

column10: b'b\' @Ocramius Yeah that could work. Is there a key for the FormElementManager in configs? I\\\'ve seen \\\'forms\\\' but that\\\'s for actual Form configs not FormElementManager. Currently the forms are defined in module configs like: I can\\\'t find any reference to a "form_element_manager" as a key anywhere in the code and there\\\'s no test for config settings in url \''
b"b' @al3xdm always use the [ ]url  as a reference ;-)'"
b'b" @Ocramius cool
column11: must have been about the only class in the repo I haven\'t been through :) Changed the service_manager config to form_elements and all appears to work. Not sure it\'s an ideal solution (seems wrong to load Forms via a FormElementManager) but I\'m happy I can at least migrate up. Thanks for the help! Not sure how I should feel about being the only person abusing Forms in this way
column12: as no one else seems to have had a problem..."'
