column10: b"b' Float (I18n) parsing trouble'"

b'b\' I\\\'ve found a trouble with float parsing in I18n (Zend\\\\I18n\\\\Validator\\\\Float). Input values:  locale: ru_RU  value: 2 000 (Russian has a "SPACE" as a decimal separator symbol) Trouble here:  \''
b"b' Did you understand this trouble? or I should write here a more useful example'"
b'b" I\'m thinking the issue here might be that the ICU library has a different separator than you are expecting: returns a comma (ASCII character 44)."'
b"b' If you consider this to be wrong
column11: file a bug report against the ICU library
column12: this is not a bug in ZF.'"

column10: b'b\' @DASPRiD @moderndeveloperllc I\\\'m not sure that it is a ICU\\\'s bug.  Let me show you what I did:1. Get an item\\\'s price from DB (for example it will be 2000)2. Convert 2000 to localized value with zf:  $value  = 2000; $filter = new NumberFormat(\\\'ru_RU\\\'); $filter->getFormatter()     ->setAttribute(NumberFormatter::MAX_FRACTION_DIGITS (100)
column11: self::MAX_FRACTION_DIGITS (100));  $value = $filter->filter((float) $value); // NOW I HAVE LOCALIZED VALUE LIKE: 2 000 it\\\'s correct3. Than after the submiting form I do a vaildate with zf: $validator = new Zend\\\\I18n\\\\Validator\\\\Float(array(\\\'locale\\\' = $validator->isValid("2 000"); // returns false It\\\'s a very strange behavior
column12: first part of zf works well but the second part gives error PS: Please test it again\''

column11: because this _can_ make a difference: Did you actually use "ru_RU" for formatting
column12: but just "ru" for validation?\''

column10: b'b\' @DASPRiD Sorry for confuse. Yes I always use the "ru_RU" format without success. \''
b'b" @esase Alright
column11: then there\'s something funky going on in ZF I suppose
column12: reopening."'

column10: b'b" I was a bit confused in that I thought we were talking about the decimal and not thousands grouping separators. I\'ll take another look. I\'m guessing something after the on line 118. I\'ll also check the filter to make sure there isn\'t an issue there."'

b'b" @DASPRiD @esase The issue is that NO-BREAK SPACE (U+00A0) is used by the locale as the grouping separator. The NumberFormat filter [changes that to a space]url  on the way out. The validator code is looking for the actual grouping separator in the string. Basically
column11: I\'ll put in around [line 126]url  to allow for either character. I\'ll also refactor the testing to be programmatic like the DateTime test I wrote. Expect a PR on Monday."'

column10: b'b" @moderndeveloperllc: Well
column11: I don\'t understand why the numberFormat filter changes that to a simple space
column12: a non-breaking space makes sense so the number doesn\'t get split into multiple lines
column13: so that should be fixed as well. The validation of course should allow both separators."'

column10: b'b" @DASPRiD My thoughts too. Running a blame puts the NumberFormat code as original to the class as created by @denixport. I can see how having a multibyte character instead of a simple space could cause issues if you are processing the number at a later point in time
column11: but we do have the NumberParse filter that should be used in that case. That and it\'s bad practice to format _then_ process. I will remove the replacement code from NumberFormat with the rest of my changes."'

b"b' Segment route always renders optional params if route has childs'"
b"b' Consider the following router setup: During module bootstrap
column11: i get my locale and set it as default lang param for router like this: If i set $lang equals to default param value (en)
column12: i receive: This behavior defined in this line of the Segment router: So
column13: if a route has child routes it will always render optional default params. What is the reason behind such behavior? Why is it done like this?'"

column10: b'b" That\'s because depending on the setup
column11: it could match the parent ambitiously. For Instance: and child
column12: the parent route allowing to terminate. If we would not enforce the optional parameters on the parent
column13: and you only supply the parameter with value
column14: the resulting URL would end up being  . Now when matching
column15: the parameter would result being and the child route would simply not match. There were actual bug reports about such behaviour
column16: which is why we introduced this check."'

column10: b"b' Well
column11: looks to me like an edge case. Is it discussable to add an option key for the route config to control this behavior?'"

column10: b'b" Sure
column11: can be discussed. I personally wouldn\'t mind (as long as the default is the current behaviour
column12: of course). Other people\'s thoughts?"'

column10: b"b' I like the idea of having that optional config key. Having an optional route param at the beginning of the route is the only way to define a language param without having to duplicate the configuration among all the routes
column11: but you will probably want to be able to create routes without that param.The same is applicable to any route param that needs to be shared among all the application once defined.'"

column10: b'b" I\'ve had the same problem and based on the work of @towr I\'ve created a module which contains a SegmentRoute. It takes an additional config key and skips the relevant sections in the route if no parameter is passed. url "'

column11: which doesn\'t match up with current behavior -it may make more sense to whitelist every skippable param?"'

column10: b'b" @whitakerbrand I\'m pretty sure (though it\'s been a while) that parameters are _not_ assumed to be skippable by default
column11: and that they have to be explicitly marked as skippable. So that should match the desired default behaviour."'

b'b" The function getLastRawRequest (in the Curl adapter in ) don\'t work in Http 1.1"'
b'b\' Hello
column11: Since the version 2.3.2 of the framework
column12: the function **getLastRawRequest() in the Curl adapter in the  don\\\'t return the last response**. The line 339 has changed in  : To **So CURLOPT_HTTP_VERSION is set to CURL_HTTP_VERSION_1_1 now** (in my case). To track the handle\\\'s request string
column13: we have to set CURLINFO_HEADER_OUT to TRUE in the curl_setopt(). But
column14: in the constructor of Zend\\\\Http\\\\Client\\\\Adapter\\\\Curl
column15: we have a list of "invalidOverwritableCurlOptions".**In it
column16: we have the option "CURL_HTTP_VERSION_1_1" (integer 2) that invalid the CURLINFO_HEADER_OUT (integer 2 too)**. I don\\\'t know if it is necessary to have the options CURL_HTTP_VERSION_1_1 and CURL_HTTP_VERSION_1_0 in the invalid option table but it broke the getLastRawRequest function in Http 1.1.I think they can be deleted from this table. Regards
column17: Fr\\xc3\\xa9d\\xc3\\xa9ric\''

column10: b"b' Please see #6485 for background info about this change.'"

b"b' Thanks for this information Martin.This change highlights the problem in : should by replaced by : **CURL_HTTP_VERSION_1_1 and CURL_HTTP_VERSION_1_0 are not curl options but the value of the option CURLOPT_HTTP_VERSION**. With this modification
column11: we will be able to set the option CURLINFO_HEADER_OUT to TRUE and getLastRawRequest will work in Http 1.1.'"

column10: b"b' @weierophinney url '"
b"b' To be sure I also updated url '"
b"b' Alternate patch: #7514 '"
b"b' Change to InputFilterFactory and CollectionInputFilter to support nested input-filter config'"

b'b" I\'ve had some difficulty implementing InputFilterFactory via array config when needing to implement nested CollectionInputFilter; Specifically when using zf-content-validation.  My use case is such that input will have nested entities (and associated input filter configurations)
column11: and my problems arose from having to explicitly rethe validators because the base InputFilterPluginManager was not available downstream. I\'m suggesting the following changes that I\'ve made to resolve this:1. Added the InputFilterPluginManager to new InputFilterFactory instances created via the Input Filter Abstract Service Factory.2. Added functionality to retrieve nested InputFilters on the CollectionInputFilter via the Service Manager if available (allowing for nested InputFilter configurations). I encourage feedback and will be happy to re-work as needed as there may be a reason the InputFilterManager wasn\'t supplied in the factory initially."'

b"b' Moving issues to their repository?'"
b'b" Hi all
column11: Zend Framework is split up into several separate repositories for a while now. At this moment this repository contains 475 open issues. Are there any plans to migrate the issues to their matching repository as well so they won\'t be forgotten and overlooked?"'

column10: b"b' Old issues are reviewed from time to time. New issues (after 2.5 split) may closed pointing to the correct issue tracker.'"
b'b" @Maks3w thanks for your fast response. So the issues are reviewed
column11: but my question was if they are being migrated to their repositories? I got 2 open issues (#5826 and #7172) and looking at the response in those issues
column12: the last review was over 8 months ago or didn\'t I understand your answer correctly? Migrating them to their repositories would probably make them much more visible. Perhaps @weierophinney can tell us more about it?"'

column10: b'b" 1. This project is made by volunteers 2. Issues are triaged so broken code is on top and  are on the bottom3. Not everybody knows everything. I\'m only focused in an small set of components and QA4. Move issues from one place to another does not fix nothing. I told because lots of issues was migrated from Jira and wasn\'t attended at all"'
b'b" I am fully aware of that. FWIW: I don\'t get payed either for contributing to ZF2 :wink: No problem
column11: I don\'t expect everybody knowing everything. You say your focus is limited to a small set of components and QA. Perhaps you can elaborate why you closed this issue?The reason for that was quite simple
column12: because I faced it myself. The issues were moved to GitHub and I had to join GitHub to access my own issues and subscribe to my issues to receive any status notifications. Furthermore the issues were pretty garbled because of the migration: alignment fell short and code blocks were barely readible. Fortunately those problems will not be there when moving issues inside GitHub
column13: because it is the same platform with the same users and references."'

column10: b'b" Matthew and I spoke briefly about this at ZendCon and there are two possibiltiies:1. Auto-close all open issues with a message asking the ticket author to re-open the ticket under the correct repository if the issue is still relevant. 2. Manually review each open issue
column11: closing the ones that are incomplete (not reproducible
column12: insufficient detail
column13: etc) and migrating the remaining ones to the correct repository. My vote is on (2)
column14: but it\'s a major endeavour to review the 475 issues that are open
column15: determine if each is valid and then copy-and-paste to the appropriate repository.  If all the issues are tagged with the component then we could use a script to do the migration automatically
column16: but that still leaves a lot of manual review work. I\'ve been slowly doing a first-pass through the open issues closing any that have insufficient detail or provide a reproducing case that now works against master.  "'

column10: b'b" Here\'s what I\'m thinking:use a script to close issues older than X months
column11: with a final comment indicating reporters should open a new  on the relevant repo if this is still a problem. We can do this _now_.Call to action to the CR team to go through the remaining open issues and ensure they are labeled with component-appropriate tags.Script to migrate issues based on tags to the appropriate repo(s). Thoughts? Anybody want to work up relevant scripts for me?"'

column10: b"b' I prefer the second option
column11: label issues by component and attend those when a refactor is in the roadmap.'"

column10: b"b' @Maks3w Matthew has given no options
column11: these are 3 steps to solve the problem. @weierophinney :+1: '"

column10: b'b\' @Maks3w nice! @froschdesign I think @Maks3w was referring to the second option from my post:I prefer this over Matthew\\\'s suggestion to bulk-close old issues with a "please reopen in the right place" comment as
column11: realistically
column12: very few are going to take the time to do that. How about this for a process flow?1. Volunteers go through all the open issues closing any that are obviously useless and tag the remaining ones with the relevant component tag(s). 2. Script auto-comments on each open issue pleading with the author to migrate the issue for us
column13: but leave the issue open.  Perhaps we can deploy a custom version of github-issue-mover to make it REALLY simple for the OP to do the migration: pre-populate the issue link and destination repository fields (or provide a choice if issue is tagged with multiple components).  I can get this bit ready while I\\\'m at TrueNorthPHP this week(end). 3. After suitable time has passed
column14: volunteers and component maintainers start combing through the remaining open issues closing or migrating them on behalf of unresponsive OPs.  If volunteers are lacking then we can just bulk-move everything to the repository of the component it\\\'s tagged with.  That should help move _some_ of the burden of dealing with these open issues back onto the OPs who want to help.  Making it super easy for them to do so should hopefully help with uptake.\''

column10: b'b\' @adamlundrigan Not "please reopen in the right place"
column11: but\\xc2\\xa0"open a new  on the relevant repo **if this is still a problem**"! [The same way like in PHPUnit.]url \''

column10: b"b' I think is possible do that if the message include a text about this repo is maintained by volunteers and we appreciate the effort for check and open the issue again'"
b'b\' @froschdesign yes
column11: I was  message similar to Sebastian\\\'s is definitely the right way
column12: but we should also make it SUPER easy for the OP to migrate the issue themselves.  Just closing with a message like "please open a new ticket in the right place if this is still an issue" puts a lot of work on them to find the right repository then copy-and-paste their issue text
column13: and IMO very few are going to do that.  Plus
column14: if they don\\\'t mention the old ticket when creating the new one any conversation thread it contained will be lost and whomever picks up the new issue to triage it has to start again from scratch. With a github-issue-mover setup like I mentioned the OP can move the issue with just two clicks
column15: three if the issue is tagged with multiple components and they have to choose which repo it should go into.  One of those clicks is to authorize GitHub access
column16: which they should only have to do once.  \''

column11: here is what I
column12: next step is to use a script to comment on those 251 issues asking the owner to migrate the issues using the tool outlined above if they think the issue is still valid
column13: or to close it if they don\'t. Set a deadline on how long they have to do this (suggest 4 weeks).3. Remaining issues if there are a manageable number we can go through them by hand and close irrelevant ones and migrate any left open by hand using the Google tool. If there are still hundreds
column14: I suggest we write a script that moves them to the tagged repo using the API and tags the original author. The downside is all the issues will be owned by a bot rather than the original owner but pragmatism Thoughts?"'
